prior_works.title: Computing Correlated Equilibria in Multi-Player Games
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the Ellipsoid Against Hope framework that computes exact correlated equilibria via separation oracles; the present paper generalizes this paradigm to bilinear zero-sum settings and to Φ-equilibria with exponentially large dimensions.

prior_works.title: Polynomial-Time Computation of Exact Correlated Equilibria in Compact Games
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Extended EAH to a broad class of compactly represented games via the polynomial-type property; the new paper builds on and transcends this by handling polyhedral/bilinear games lacking polynomial type through a different oracle-based generalization.

prior_works.title: Computing Extensive-Form Correlated Equilibria
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Modified the EAH method to compute exact EFCE despite the lack of polynomial type in extensive-form games; the present work abstracts and broadens that idea into a unified ellipsoid-style framework for polyhedral/bilinear games using weaker response oracles.

prior_works.title: Extensive-Form Correlated Equilibrium: Definition and Characterization
prior_works.role: Equilibrium concept underpinning the target solutions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Defined and studied EFCE, a key instance of the Φ-equilibrium family the new framework can compute exactly, anchoring the equilibrium notions targeted by the algorithmic generalization.

prior_works.title: Efficient Computation of Equilibria for Extensive-Form Games (Sequence Form)
prior_works.authors: Daphne Koller, Nimrod Megiddo, Bernhard von Stengel
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the sequence-form representation that renders extensive-form strategy spaces polyhedral and payoffs bilinear; this structural basis is crucial for framing Φ-equilibrium computation as saddle-point problems in bilinear zero-sum polyhedral games.

prior_works.title: Geometric Algorithms and Combinatorial Optimization
prior_works.authors: Martin Grötschel, László Lovász, Alexander Schrijver
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the separation–optimization paradigm underlying ellipsoid-based algorithms; the new method leverages this theory to solve saddle points with exponentially many variables via oracle access.

prior_works.title: A Sublinear-Time Randomized Approximation Algorithm for Matrix Games
prior_works.authors: M. D. Grigoriadis, L. G. Khachiyan
prior_works.role: Oracle-based game solving with approximate responses
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated that large zero-sum games can be tackled via response oracles (e.g., best/approximate responses); the present work echoes this oracle philosophy, formalizing a weaker 'good-enough-response' oracle yet achieving exact computation through an ellipsoid-style framework.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core innovation—a general ellipsoid-style framework that computes exact Φ-equilibria (saddle points) in polyhedral bilinear zero-sum games even when one dimension is exponentially large and only a good-enough-response oracle is available—emerges by synthesizing several direct precedents. The Ellipsoid Against Hope of Papadimitriou and Roughgarden pioneered the use of separation oracles to compute exact correlated equilibria in succinct games. Jiang and Leyton-Brown formalized the polynomial-type condition that ensures EAH’s applicability in compact representations, delineating the boundary that extensive-form games typically violate. Huang’s adaptation showed that, despite failing polynomial type, one can still engineer EAH-like machinery to compute exact extensive-form correlated equilibria, foreshadowing the present paper’s broader generalization.

On the modeling side, the sequence-form representation of Koller, Megiddo, and von Stengel supplies the polyhedral and bilinear structure that allows extensive-form (and related) games to be cast as saddle-point problems with exponentially many pure strategies but polynomially describable convex strategy sets. Forges and von Stengel’s EFCE concept identifies a central target equilibrium notion within the Φ-equilibria family that the new algorithm explicitly handles. The theoretical backbone is the separation–optimization equivalence from Grötschel–Lovász–Schrijver, enabling ellipsoid-based handling of exponentially large spaces via oracles. Finally, the oracle-driven ethos of Grigoriadis–Khachiyan—solving large games using (approximate) response oracles—directly inspires the paper’s key relaxation to a good-enough-response oracle while still attaining exact solutions through refined cutting-plane/ellipsoid control. Collectively, these works converge to make exact, polynomial-time computation of Φ-equilibria in polyhedral games feasible.
